item.title: Modeling the effect of surface roughness
item.description: A key topic of fluid mechanics is that surface roughness with a height of 10-100 Î¼m significantly affects flow losses. Irregular roughness increases the loss, but streamwise elongated riblets decrease it.

item.title: Delaying laminar-turbulent transition using elastic coatings
item.description: In liquids, the laminar-turbulent transition can be delayed, which can reduce the flow losses. The topic aims at more sophisticated modelling and design of elastic coatings than in previous studies.

item.title: Delaying laminar-turbulent transition using Miniature Vortex Generators (MVGs).
item.description: Vortex generators are tipically used to delay separation, thereby reducing the profile drag. Recent studies have shown both theoretically and experimentally that properly designed vortex generators can delay the laminar-turbulent transitions, and reduce the friction drag significantly.

item.title: Development of new instability investigation tools
item.description: Predicting the onset of turbulence is one of the most challenging problems in fluid mechanics, especially in a strong external disturbance environment. The motivation of this topic is that as turbulence can significantly affect flow losses and transport phenomena, prediction of its onset would have a lot of practical applications.

item.title: Reduced order modeling of the cavity tone
item.description: The cavity tone is one of the simplest aeroacoustic configurations. The flow above a cavity creates a shear layer that is unstable and tends to oscillate.

item.title: Reduced order modeling of the edge tone
item.description: The edge tone is one of the simplest aeroacoustic configurations. It consists of a plane jet opposite to a wedge. The jet oscillates with well-defined frequencies as it impinges the wedge, and can also produce sound.
